data.title: remote debugging isn't working
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.4.0
- OS Version:ubuntu 16.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. run an app on debug more `node --debug`
2. try to connect to the remote server ip running the debugger
3. it will stop if you specified the --debug-brk option on the first line but once when you hit continue it no longer stops in the break points you specify in vscode 

not: i havent tried using `debugger` keyword inside code since its already on the server its not the best way i think

data.title: VScode unstable editing a very long CSS file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0 / 1.5.0-insiders
- OS Version: Windows 7 64bits / Windows 10 64bits

I'm editing a very long ~11.000 lines CSS file (attached), and VSCode is behaving surprising well, but I've found some problems:

[global.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/409009/global.zip)

1- TAB insertion is very slow, every time I push TAB the editor halt for about 1 second.
2- Sometimes the editor becomes unresponsive, and a popup instructs me to close or restart
3- Sometimes seems that only Monaco halts. I can change tabs, etc, but I can't edit any file.

That usually happens when I'm editing near the end of the file. Extensions make things worse, but I can reproduce the problem without any extensions.

To reproduce: try to type fast and use TAB and ENTER as much as possible. CTRL+S from time to time. In my tests I can hang the editor just hitting TAB and ENTER like a maniac.

I'm really "ok" about some slowness giving the size of the file, but I believe that the editor should try not to hang and lose the user work.

![2016-08-09 10_24_58-program manager](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6965667/17517866/c0e124a0-5e1b-11e6-8eda-aec9b9a18e68.png)

data.title: Make find widget toggles configurable settings

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Related to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4309#issuecomment-225023802

Add to `settings.json` a way to always enable the case-sensitivity feature of Find.

2. create a second folder by selecting project. second folder will be under first folder instead of being under projet as for first folder

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

There is some invisiable ASCII 01 chars in my file. In Sublime Text and Notepad++  they can be displayed as 'SOH'. Here in VSCode not. 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use this String from https://gist.github.com/lqiang79/2013d793f90821d7fa8191b6e6daee42, copy past into the notepad++ adn VSCode, you can see different

Maybe an auto render for all of the ASCII Control Characters.

data.title: Breakpoints in extension debug can't be hit
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise(10.0.14393) And Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set breakpoints in extension typescript code.
2. Press `F5` to start the debugging, the breakpoints seem to be getting hit, but the editor isn't getting updated, and debugger window is empty, the debug breakpoints are disabled. I have to hit the continue button a couple of times before the debugger kicks in.

@DonJayamanne also met the same issue

The issue was originally posted in #10160

data.title: Explore open/install an extension from the Market Place
data.body:
The idea here is to support URLs such as `vscode:extension/${UUID}`. These could make Code open that extension in its UI, allowing for a fast path towards extension installation from the Marketplace.

Code is in https://github.com/joaomoreno/vscode/tree/urlservice
- [x] Propagate Electron's `app.on('open-url')` to the last focused Window
- [x] Make Extension contribution listen on `onOpenUrl` events and open the extension UI
- [x] Figure out how to do the same when Code is not running    69e8c7a
- [x] Implement for Windows 8609a07
- [x] Talk to Marketplace guys about this, along with a demo @waderyan 
- [x] Coordinate with @hamenon on the UI for the marketplace @waderyan
- [x] Create docs for figuring out your VS Code version @waderyan

data.title: tabSize affects indentation

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.4.0 (6276dcb0ae497766056b4c09ea75be1d76a8b679, 2016-08-04T16:49:32.489Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-34-generic

`tabSize` setting has two independent functions:
1. Size of tabulation character.
2. Size of indentation.

The latter is really useful. But its connectedness with the former makes it unusable. In one file tabulation character size may be 8 and indentation size may be 4. How can I control these two values with one setting?

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 8.1 enterprise

Issue:
1. There was an update for my VSC on 8th August 2016 - the date in the about information says 2016-08-04, post this update the colorisation stops part way down the file
2. A JSON file of 6076 lines, the colour stops at line 1242
3. A JSON file of 2628 lines, colour stops at line 1777

data.title: Filter TypeScript errors for selected files
data.body:
Hi, first of all, thanks for the awesome project. You're doing fantastic work.

I am in the process of gradually moving a codebase to using TypeScript. There are certain compiler options which I want to enable, namely no implicit any and strict null checking, however because I am moving things gradually, I only want to enforce these stricter rules on a subset of TypeScript files.

My solution to this is to wrap the TypeScript compiler, filtering out error messages from no implicit any and strict null checking where the file is not whitelisted as “strict”. For example: https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/8855#issuecomment-237915223

However, I do not want to use such a solution in my project without corresponding feedback in my IDEs.

Is there any way I can wrap the TypeScript compiler used in vscode similarly to how I wrapped the TypeScript compiler in https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/8855#issuecomment-237915223?

Or, perhaps I could use my wrapped compiler and send those errors to vscode instead of using the built in TypeScript errors?

Is there somewhere I can find the code that sends the TypeScript errors to vscode?

I want to achieve this for other plugins in other IDEs too, to suit all the developers in my team, but also because I think this will be useful to other people who are gradually moving their codebase to TypeScript and want to start using some of the stricter compiler options.

Thanks,
Olly

data.title: Non-ASCII characters get automatically replaced with other ones

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Sometimes, when I open a file, then save that file and close it, certain (non-ASCII) characters get replaced with other ones, and this causes problems. It's not a serious issue, but it's annoying.

To reproduce, create a file which contains only the "0x93" byte. Open it with VS Code, don't do any change to it, save it, close the editor and hexdump it. After saving it the file contains "0xEF 0xBF 0xBD".

Details:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 7

data.title: Monaco uses outline-offset css which is not supported in IE/Edge
data.body:
Basically, the bug is that Monaco uses the CSS “outline-offset” with high contrast styling, but this is not supported in IE (or Edge).  See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/outline-offset.  This results in some wacky looking scrollbar outlines, as shown below from Edge.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/17507624/ef4b5cb2-5e10-11e6-97fb-37bf4c1c01b5.png)

data.title: High CPU usage and poor performance using the integrated terminal on Windows
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 - Version 1511 (OS Build 10586.494)
- Installed Extensions: csharp (1.3.0)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch VS Code.
2. Open the integrated terminal (CTRL+~).
3. Type some text into the terminal.

Expected:

The text appears promptly upon entering, and CPU usage shows no spikes.

Actual:

The text does not appear immediately.  Task Manager shows one of the VSCode processes is using nearly 100% of a CPU core for around 1-2 seconds.  Afterwards, the input text appears in the terminal, and CPU usage drops to minimal values.

Notes:

After rebooting my machine, VSCode initially performs as expected.  However, performance will eventually drop considerably and stay consistently poor even after relaunching VSCode.  Only a full reboot seems to temporarily address the issue.

While I do not have full Visual Studio or the performance toolkit on this machine to be able to capture more detailed profiling data, I was able to use Task Manager to capture a minidump of the process during the high CPU usage.  As the resulting file is about 350MB, I will defer uploading until someone requests it.

[DxDiag.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/408305/DxDiag.txt)

data.title: Shortcuts to open left panel should close it if it's already opened

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10; Fedora 24

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Open VSC, close the left panel (to only show the editor).
2. Press a shortcut to open the left panel, for examle: `Ctrl-Shift-E`, `Ctrl-Shift-X`...
3. Press the same shortcut in step `#2` again. VSC won't close the panel.

---

I often work with 150-columns per line code base, and not use the left panel much. So space is value. Would you consider adding support to close the left panel by shortcut, if it's already opened?

Thank you,

data.title: Debug console: pressing tab no longer leaves input
data.body: When you tab into the debug console input you can no longer tab out making it a stop for any accessibility operation. I think we should detect "Tab" and "Shift+Tab" and leave the editor there.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0 and lower
- OS Version: Mac OS X - El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Write some Node 4.x compatible ES6
2. Try to run debugger
3. It will error out

I can't for the life of me figure out how to upgrade NodeJS JUST for the debugger. I can do it in the built in terminal just fine, but it does not reflect on the Debugger. I am still stuck on 0.10.x. Is this a known issue?

data.title: File > Open > open a folder does not work on the first attempt

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open new VSCode window
2. In the menu bar, File > Open > select a folder

Every time I try to open a folder using this method, I need to repeat the steps twice in order for the folder to open in my VSCode editor.
